content.text: Title: Principles of Programming Code: EP17.CNTT1128E
Credits: 3 (45 credit hours; 1 credit hour = 50 minutes of lecture)
Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
Lecture: 30 hrs
Exercises on class: 15 hrs
Exercise and discussion (Tutor): 15 hrs
Self-study: 90 hrs.
Parallel course(s): None
Prerequisite course(s): Introduction of Information Technology, Discrete Mathematics
Department conducting the course:
Faculty: Information Technology, R1310, 13th flr., Building A1, The National Economics University, 207 Giai Phong Road, Hai Ba Trung District, Hanoi, Vietnam.
Lecturers:
PhD. Phạm Xuân Lâm Email: lampx@neu.edu.vn
MA. Nguyễn Quỳnh Mai Email: mainq@neu.edu.vn
PhD. Phạm Minh Hoàn Email: hoanpm@neu.edu.vn
MA. Cao Thị Thu Hương Email: huongct@neu.edu.vn
MA. Trần Thị Mỹ Diệp Email: diepttm@neu.edu.vn
PhD. Tống Thị Hảo Tâm Email: tamtth@neu.edu.vn
PhD. Lê Thị Hoài Thu Email: thulh@neu.edu.vn
MA. Phạm Thảo Email: thaop@neu.edu.vn
PhD. Nguyễn Thanh Hương Email: huongnt_cntt@neu.edu.vn
Kind of the course:
Course language: In English
This course provides basic knowledge about methods, programming thinking and solving problems on computers such as: basic programming structures, algorithms, data structure.

The course trains learners with basic computer programming skills through the C programming language and the ability to research, analyze and design functional modules. In addition, this course equips learners with the necessary knowledge and skills to apply the learned thinking and knowledge in the study of related subsequent programming subjects in the training program.
Course Book(s):
[1]. Jeri R. Hanly, Elliot B. Koffman. Problem Solving and Program Design in C, (8th Edition)
Reference Book(s):
[2]. Pham Van At (2020). Basic and Advanced C Programming Techniques, Bach Khoa Publishing House
[3] Applied C: An Introduction and More. McGraw – Hill Higher Education
Software(s):
[1] Visual Studio Code
[2] Code::Blocks

content.text: Table 5.1. Course learning outcomes

cells: Describe the basic concepts of programming, the process of solving problems on computers, basic data types and structured data types, programming structures. Provide basic and popular algorithms. Explanation of function, pointer and their meaning and usage

column_map.CLO Description: Apply knowledge of programming structures (branching, iteration), algorithms and data types to write programs

cells: Practice, program to solve real problems.

column_map.CLO Description: Practice, program to solve real problems.

cells: Have skills in searching, collecting, synthesizing and analyzing to solve problems using C programming language.

column_map.CLO Description: Have skills in searching, collecting, synthesizing and analyzing to solve problems using C programming language.

cells: Have coordination skills to solve group assignments, ensure completion of work on schedule

cells: Skilled in using tools to optimize code and reduce programming time.

content.text: Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).

Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
Students will be awarded points for constructive comments these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.

Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.

full_text:
Title: Principles of Programming Code: EP17.CNTT1128E
Credits: 3 (45 credit hours; 1 credit hour = 50 minutes of lecture)
Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
Lecture: 30 hrs
Exercises on class: 15 hrs
Exercise and discussion (Tutor): 15 hrs
Self-study: 90 hrs.
Parallel course(s): None
Prerequisite course(s): Introduction of Information Technology, Discrete Mathematics
Department conducting the course:
Faculty: Information Technology, R1310, 13th flr., Building A1, The National Economics University, 207 Giai Phong Road, Hai Ba Trung District, Hanoi, Vietnam.
Lecturers:
PhD. Phạm Xuân Lâm Email: lampx@neu.edu.vn
MA. Nguyễn Quỳnh Mai Email: mainq@neu.edu.vn
PhD. Phạm Minh Hoàn Email: hoanpm@neu.edu.vn
MA. Cao Thị Thu Hương Email: huongct@neu.edu.vn
MA. Trần Thị Mỹ Diệp Email: diepttm@neu.edu.vn
PhD. Tống Thị Hảo Tâm Email: tamtth@neu.edu.vn
PhD. Lê Thị Hoài Thu Email: thulh@neu.edu.vn
MA. Phạm Thảo Email: thaop@neu.edu.vn
PhD. Nguyễn Thanh Hương Email: huongnt_cntt@neu.edu.vn
Kind of the course:
Course language: In English
This course provides basic knowledge about methods, programming thinking and solving problems on computers such as: basic programming structures, algorithms, data structure.
The course trains learners with basic computer programming skills through the C programming language and the ability to research, analyze and design functional modules. In addition, this course equips learners with the necessary knowledge and skills to apply the learned thinking and knowledge in the study of related subsequent programming subjects in the training program.
Course Book(s):
[1]. Jeri R. Hanly, Elliot B. Koffman. Problem Solving and Program Design in C, (8th Edition)
Reference Book(s):
[2]. Pham Van At (2020). Basic and Advanced C Programming Techniques, Bach Khoa Publishing House
[3] Applied C: An Introduction and More. McGraw – Hill Higher Education
Software(s):
[1] Visual Studio Code
[2] Code::Blocks

Table 8. Lesson plan for the course
Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).
Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
Students will be awarded points for constructive comments these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.
Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.
